questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. A rapid antigen detection test for Group A Streptococcus is positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe oral penicillin V for 10 days
Perform a throat culture to confirm the diagnosis
Administer a single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Prescribe oral penicillin V for 10 days

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this case is Group A Streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • Oral penicillin V for 10 days is the first-line treatment for Group A Streptococcal pharyngitis in most cases. It helps prevent rheumatic fever. The 10-day course is recommended to ensure complete eradication of the organism.

 

Gram Stain

Gram-positive cocci in chains

Appearance on Blood Agar
  • Pinpoint colonies with a wide zone of hemolysis
  • Indicates beta-hemolysis

Transport Medium

Pike's media

Selective Media

PNF (Phenylethyl alcohol agar), Crystal Violet Blood Agar (CVBA)

Liquid Media
  • Granular turbidity
  • Suggests the presence of streptococci, as these organisms can cause cloudiness in liquid media.

Biochemical Tests

Result
  • Catalase Test

Negative
  • Oxidase Test

Negative
  • PYR Test

Positive
  • Bacitracin Sensitivity

Sensitive


 

Antibiotic

Dosage (Children)

Dosage (Adolescents/Adults)

Special Notes

Penicillin V (Oral)

250 mg 2–3 times daily for 10 days

250 mg 4 times daily or 500 mg twice daily for 10 days

First-line oral treatment; is effective and inexpensive.

Amoxicillin (Oral)
  • 50 mg/kg once daily (max 1000 mg) or 25 mg/kg twice daily (max 500 mg) for 10 days

N/A

Preferred for younger children due to better palatability; similar efficacy to penicillin.

Benzathine Penicillin G (IM)
  • 600,000 U (for children <27 kg) 1 dose
  • 1,200,000 U (for children ≥27 kg) 1 dose

N/A

For patients who cannot tolerate oral therapy or have poor adherence to a 10-day regimen.

 

Other options:

 

Perform Throat Culture(Option B): for Group A Streptococcus has high specificity. A positive Rapid Antigen Detection Test result in a symptomatic patient is sufficient for diagnosis and treatment initiation without the need for throat culture confirmation.

 

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G (Option C): is not the first-line option for uncomplicated cases. Usually reserved for patients who cannot tolerate oral medication or where compliance is a concern.

 

Azithromycin (Option D): is an alternative for patients with penicillin allergy. However, it is not the first-line treatment due to increasing resistance rates and should be reserved for specific situations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a persistent cough and purulent sputum. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and frequent respiratory infections. A sputum sample is sent for culture, which grows a gram-negative diplococcus that is oxidase positive and butyrate esterase positive. What is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Moraxella catarrhalis

 

Explanation:

Moraxella catarrhalis is a gram-negative diplococcus that is oxidase positive and butyrate esterase positive. It is commonly associated with respiratory tract infections, especially in individuals with chronic lung conditions like COPD.

Moraxella Catarrhalis and Lacunata:

Characteristic

Moraxella Catarrhalis

Moraxella Lacunata (axenfeld)

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci

Gram-negative coccobacilli

Growth on Blood Agar and Chocolate Agar

Smooth, opaque, grayish-white colonies

Smooth, spreading colonies with a pit in the center

Catalase Test

Positive

Positive

Oxidase Test

Positive

Positive

DNase Test

Positive

Negative

Butyrate Esterase Test

Positive

Negative

Nitrate Reduction Test

Positive

Positive

Sugar Fermentation

Does not ferment sugars

Does not ferment sugars

Common Infections

Otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia

Conjunctivitis (not a common pathogen)

Virulence Factors

Beta-lactamase production, immune evasion mechanisms

Less characterized

Typical Symptoms

Ear pain, nasal congestion, cough, fever, respiratory distress

Redness, itching, discharge from the eyes

Transmission

Respiratory droplets

Direct contact with contaminated surfaces or secretions

Antibiotic Susceptibility

Generally susceptible to beta-lactamase inhibitors, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones

Typically sensitive to similar antibiotics but less commonly treated due to lower pathogenicity

M. Lacunata (Option A) is generally associated with ocular infections, such as conjunctivitis, and is not typically found in respiratory infections. Additionally, Moraxella lacunata is DNase negative and butyrate esterase negative

N. Meningitidis (Option B) is a gram-negative diplococcus and oxidase positive, it is primarily associated with meningitis and septicemia, not respiratory infections. It does not produce butyrate esterase.

H. Influenzae (Option D) is a gram-negative coccobacillus, not a diplococcus. While it can cause respiratory infections, it does not match the described gram stain and biochemical characteristics.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 5-day history of dysuria and purulent urethral discharge. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. Gram stain of the urethral discharge reveals gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Ceftriaxone

 

Explanation:

Ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for gonococcal infections due to its efficacy and low resistance rates. It is recommended to administer it intramuscularly at a dose of 500 mg for uncomplicated gonorrhea.

 

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae:

 

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

 

Azithromycin (Option B) is an alternative treatment if ceftriaxone is unavailable or if the patient has a severe allergy to cephalosporins.

 

Doxycycline (Option C) is used to treat co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis but is not effective as monotherapy for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It should be used in conjunction with ceftriaxone for comprehensive treatment.

 

Ciprofloxacin (Option D): Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, were previously used for gonococcal infections, but due to widespread resistance, they are no longer recommended as a first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents to the emergency department with high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and a petechial rash. Lumbar puncture is performed, and the CSF analysis shows elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of neutrophils, elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. Gram stain reveals gram-negative diplococci, confirming Neisseria meningitidis. What is the most appropriate initial empirical antibiotic therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Ceftriaxone

 

Explanation:

Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that is highly effective against Neisseria meningitidis. It penetrates the blood-brain barrier well and provides broad-spectrum coverage against other possible bacterial pathogens in cases of bacterial meningitis. Cefotaxime is an alternative with similar efficacy.

 

Empirical Antibiotic Therapy:

  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: First-line treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Vancomycin: Added empirically to cover potential penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae until the pathogen is identified. (Option B ruled out)
  • Ampicillin: Added if Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, especially in immunocompromised patients and the elderly. (Option C ruled out)

Definitive Therapy:

  • Penicillin G: The antibiotic of choice for confirmed Neisseria meningitidis, given intravenously.
  • Alternative Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime can be continued if the pathogen is confirmed to be susceptible.
  • Duration: Treatment typically lasts 7 days.

Dexamethasone: May be used to reduce inflammation and neurological complications, particularly if started before or with the first dose of antibiotics.

Chemoprophylaxis for Close Contacts:

  • Rifampin: 600 mg every 12 hours for 2 days (adults); 10 mg/kg every 12 hours for 2 days (children).
  • Ciprofloxacin: A single dose of 500 mg (adults); not typically used in children. (Option D ruled out)
  • Ceftriaxone: A single intramuscular dose of 250 mg (adults) or 125 mg (children).

Vaccination Prophylaxis:

Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines (serogroups A, C, Y, and W135) administered as 2 doses to children aged 3-18 months or a single dose to older children and adults.

It is not given to children less than 2-3 years of age.

Indications-

  1. Contacts of patients during outbreaks
  2. Splenic dysfunction
  3. Terminal complement component deficiency
  4. International travelers

questions.text: Which of the following findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would most strongly suggest a diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis infection?

choices.text: Low Neutrophil count, normal protein, normal glucose
High Neutrophil count, high protein, low glucose
High Neutrophil count, low protein, normal glucose
Low Neutrophil count, high protein, high glucose

questions.solution:
Answer: B) High white blood cell count, high protein, low glucose

 

Explanation:

These findings are characteristic of bacterial meningitis, including meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis. A high Neutrophil count indicates an inflammatory response, high protein levels indicate increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier, and low glucose levels indicate bacterial consumption of glucose in the CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following tests would best help to differentiate Neisseria meningitidis from Neisseria gonorrhoeae in this clinical context?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Carbohydrate utilization test

 

Explanation:

The carbohydrate utilization test differentiates N. meningitidis from N. gonorrhoeae based on their ability to oxidize different sugars. N. meningitidis oxidizes both glucose and maltose, while N. gonorrhoeae oxidizes only glucose.


 

Differences between N. Gonorrhoeae and N. Meningitidis:

 

Characteristic

Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Neisseria meningitidis

Morphology

Gram-negative diplococci

Kidney shaped

Gram-negative diplococci with capsule

Oxidase Test

Positive

Positive

Catalase Test

Positive

Positive

Habitat

Human genitourinary tract

Human nasopharynx

Transmission

Sexual contact

Respiratory droplets, close contact

Diseases Caused

Gonorrhea, pelvic inflammatory disease, conjunctivitis in newborns

Meningitis, septicemia (meningococcemia)

Virulence Factors

Pili, outer membrane proteins, lipooligosaccharides (LOS)

Polysaccharide capsule, pili, outer membrane proteins, LOS

Culture Media

Thayer-Martin agar, Chocolate agar

Thayer-Martin agar, Chocolate agar

Carbohydrate Utilization

Glucose positive, maltose negative

Glucose positive, maltose positive

Superoxol Test

Strong positive with 30% hydrogen peroxide

Weak or negative reaction

Antibiotic Resistance

Increasing resistance, especially to penicillin and fluoroquinolones

Generally susceptible to penicillin, but resistance can occur

Vaccination

No vaccine available

Vaccines available for various serogroups (A, C, W, Y, B)

Epidemiology

Common STD worldwide

Causes outbreaks, especially in crowded settings

Oxidase test (Option A): Both Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are oxidase positive.

Gram stain morphology (Option B): Both organisms appear as gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain. This test helps to identify the general appearance of the bacteria.

Bile esculin test (Option C): It is typically used to differentiate enterococci and group D streptococci, which can hydrolyze esculin in the presence of bile.

questions.text: A clinical microbiology laboratory is performing biochemical tests to identify a strain of gamma-hemolytic streptococci isolated from a blood culture. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to differentiate Streptococcus bovis from other gamma-hemolytic streptococci?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bile esculin test

Explanation:

  • The bile esculin test is used to differentiate enterococci (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis, Enterococcus faecium) from other streptococci. Streptococcus bovis is positive in this test due to its ability to hydrolyze esculin in the presence of bile.
  • Gamma-hemolytic streptococci (also known as non-hemolytic streptococci) do not lyse red blood cells, so they do not produce a clear zone around colonies on blood agar. 
  • They can grow in the presence of 40% bile, 6.5% NaCl, pH 9.6, and 45 degrees Celsius and can be further classified into different groups based on their biochemical and serological characteristics
    • Includes groups such as Streptococcus bovis, Streptococcus equinus, and others within the Enterococcus genus.
    • These organisms are often part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract but can also cause infections in humans, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Clinical Relevance

Infections: Can cause a range of infections including urinary tract infections, bacteremia, intra-abdominal infections, and wound infections.

Endocarditis: Streptococcus bovis is particularly associated with infective endocarditis, often in patients with underlying gastrointestinal malignancies or colon disorders.

Laboratory Diagnosis

Gram Stain: Gram-positive oval cocci are often arranged in chains or pairs.

Culture:

  • Growth on blood agar without hemolysis.
  • Growth on Mac Conkey medium- tiny magenta colony

Biochemical Tests: Differentiation within the group using tests like bile esculin agar (positive for Enterococcus), PYR test (positive for Enterococcus), and other biochemical markers.

Treatment

Antibiotics: Generally susceptible to penicillin and ampicillin, although some strains, especially within the Enterococcus genus, may exhibit resistance to multiple antibiotics.

Treatment of Endocarditis: Combination therapy with aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) is often used for synergy, particularly in cases of enterococcal endocarditis.

Epidemiology

Common in the gastrointestinal tract, especially in elderly or immunocompromised patients

Streptococcus bovis is associated with colorectal cancer and inflammatory bowel disease, warranting screening for these conditions in patients with the bacterium

 

Optochin susceptibility test (Option A) is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae (susceptible to optochin) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.

PYR test (Option B) is used to identify group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes), which are beta-hemolytic. It is also used to further classify gamma haemolytic Streptococcus.

CAMP test (Option D) is used to identify group B streptococci (Streptococcus agalactiae) by demonstrating enhanced hemolysis when plated adjacent to a Staphylococcus aureus streak.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to her primary care physician for an annual check-up. She asks about vaccines recommended for adults to prevent pneumonia. Which of the following vaccines would be most appropriate to recommend to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine (PPSV)

Explanation:

  • PPSV is recommended for adults over 65 years old and younger adults with certain medical conditions, such as COPD, chronic heart disease, or diabetes. It covers a broader range of pneumococcal serotypes compared to PCV and helps prevent pneumococcal pneumonia and invasive diseases in adults.

 

Treatment for Strep Pneumoniae

Vaccines for Strep Pneumoniae
  • Penicillin and Penicillin Derivatives: Effective for susceptible strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae. High-dose penicillin G or amoxicillin is the treatment of choice for non-severe infections.
  • Cephalosporins: Such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime are used for more severe infections or in patients with penicillin allergy.
  • Macrolides: Such as erythromycin or azithromycin, may be used in cases of resistance or intolerance to beta-lactams.
  • Supportive care including antipyretics, oxygen therapy, and fluids as needed.

Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV): Contains polysaccharide antigens from the most common serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a carrier protein.

  • Recommended for infants and young children to prevent invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), pneumonia, and otitis media.(Option A ruled out)
  • It's a seven-valent conjugate vaccine.

Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine (PPSV):

  • Covers a broader range of pneumococcal serotypes compared to PCV.
  • Recommended for adults over 65 years old, and younger adults with certain medical conditions (e.g., immunocompromised, chronic heart or lung disease).

Varicella vaccine (Option B) is used to prevent chickenpox caused by the Varicella zoster virus. It is recommended for the elderly but is not relevant for preventing pneumococcal infections in adults.

Hib vaccine (Option C) is used to prevent infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b, such as meningitis, pneumonia, and epiglottitis, primarily in children under 5 years old.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, productive cough with rust-colored sputum, and pleuritic chest pain. His medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A chest X-ray reveals a lobar consolidation. Sputum Gram stain shows gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on the sputum
Bile solubility test on the sputum sample

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Blood culture

Explanation:

Blood cultures are important in diagnosing invasive pneumococcal diseases, including pneumonia, as they can identify the presence of bacteria in the bloodstream and confirm the diagnosis. The success of this test is directly related to the methods used to collect the blood sample. The most important factor that determines the success of a blood culture is the volume of blood processed. Approximately 20 ml of blood should be collected from an adult for each blood culture, and proportionally smaller volumes should be collected from children and neonates. Blood cultures are more specific and help confirm systemic involvement, which is important in moderate to severe pneumonia.

 

Diseases caused by Strep pneumonia:

Pneumonia

Community-acquired pneumonia, is often characterized by rapid onset, high fever, chills, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough with rust-colored sputum.

Meningitis

A common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults and children, presenting with symptoms like headache, fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, and altered mental status.

Otitis Media

A frequent cause of middle ear infections in children, characterized by ear pain, fever, irritability, and sometimes hearing loss.

Sinusitis

Causes acute sinus infections, presenting with facial pain, nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and fever.

Endocarditis

Can cause endocarditis, particularly in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions.

Lab investigations-

Gram Stain:
  • Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci.
  • Useful in the initial identification of clinical specimens like sputum, blood, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

Culture
  • Grows well on blood agar, producing alpha-hemolytic (greenish) colonies.
  • Optochin sensitivity test: S. pneumoniae is sensitive to optochin, differentiating it from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.
  • Bile solubility test: S. pneumoniae is bile soluble, confirming its identity

Blood Culture

  • Critical for diagnosing invasive pneumococcal disease and guiding antibiotic therapy.

Antigen Detection:
  • Latex agglutination or immunochromatographic tests for pneumococcal antigens in urine or CSF.
  • Rapid diagnostic tool, especially useful in meningitis cases.

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
  • Detection of pneumococcal DNA in clinical specimens.
  • Highly sensitive and specific, useful for diagnosing invasive pneumococcal disease

Quellung Reaction:
  • Capsular swelling test where specific antisera cause the capsule of S. pneumoniae to swell, confirming its presence and serotype

Throat swab culture (Option A) is not appropriate for diagnosing pneumonia. They are primarily used for diagnosing streptococcal pharyngitis, which is typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on the sputum (Option C): While PCR is highly sensitive and specific for detecting pneumococcal DNA, it is not typically the first step in standard diagnostic protocols

Bile solubility test on the sputum sample (Option D) is used to confirm the identity of Streptococcus pneumoniae from isolated colonies, not directly from sputum samples. It is a secondary confirmatory test once the organism has been cultured.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease and a prosthetic mitral valve undergoes a tooth extraction. Two weeks later, she presents with fever, night sweats, and malaise. Blood cultures reveal alpha-hemolytic Streptococcus viridans. Transesophageal echocardiography shows vegetations on the mitral valve. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start oral amoxicillin and schedule follow-up in one week
Admit to the hospital and start intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin
Discharge with a prescription for oral clindamycin and instruct her to return if symptoms worsen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Admit to the hospital and start intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin

Explanation:

  • Intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin are often used together in treating infective endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans, especially in patients with prosthetic valves, as combination therapy can be synergistic and more effective in eradicating the infection.
  • Most commonly affecting prosthetic valve <12 months after replacement- Staph epidermidis
  • More than 12 months after replacement- Strep viridans

 

Alpha Hemolytic Streptococcus:

  • Part of the normal flora of the human mouth, throat, and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Exhibits alpha-hemolysis on blood agar, leading to a partial or greenish discoloration around colonies.
  • Includes multiple species such as S. mitis, S. mutans, S. sanguinis (leads to SABE), and S. salivarius.

Epidemiology:
  • Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis.
  • Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk.

Infection Mechanism:
  • Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics.
  • Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues.

Clinical Presentation:
  • Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages.
  • Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction.

Diagnosis:
  • Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism.
  • Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves

Treatment:
  • Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves.

 

Start oral amoxicillin and schedule follow-up in one week (Option A): Oral antibiotics are not appropriate for treating endocarditis due to the need for high, sustained bactericidal concentrations in the bloodstream.

Discharge with a prescription for oral clindamycin and instruct her to return if symptoms worsen (Option C): Oral antibiotics are not appropriate for treating endocarditis due to the need for high, sustained bactericidal concentrations in the bloodstream.

Schedule urgent valve replacement surgery (Option D): While valve replacement surgery (Option D) may eventually be necessary, the immediate next step is to control the infection with appropriate intravenous antibiotics. Surgery is considered if there is severe valve dysfunction, heart failure, or persistent infection despite antibiotics.

questions.text: A 36-week pregnant woman presents for routine prenatal care. Her GBS culture from 35 weeks gestation is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient during labor?

choices.text: Administer intravenous ampicillin every 4 hours until delivery
Prescribe oral penicillin for 7 days prior to expected delivery date
Administer a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone at the onset of labor
No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Administer intravenous ampicillin every 4 hours until delivery

 

Explanation:

Intravenous ampicillin (or penicillin) administered every 4 hours during labor until delivery is the recommended intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) for GBS-positive mothers. This approach significantly reduces the risk of early-onset GBS disease in newborns.

 

GBS prevention:

 

1. Screening: Universal screening of pregnant women at 35-37 weeks gestation is recommended in many countries.

 

2. Indications for IAP:

  • Positive GBS screening culture during current pregnancy
  • GBS bacteriuria during current pregnancy
  • Previous infant with invasive GBS disease
  • Unknown GBS status with risk factors (preterm labor, prolonged rupture of membranes, intrapartum fever)

 

3. Antibiotics:

  • First-line: Penicillin G or Ampicillin
  • For penicillin-allergic patients: Cefazolin (if low risk for anaphylaxis) or Clindamycin/Vancomycin (if high risk for anaphylaxis and isolate susceptible)

 

In case the newborn gets infected, antibiotics like penicillin and other supportive management are used for treatment.

 

Prescribe oral penicillin for 7 days prior to expected delivery date (Option B): Oral antibiotics are not effective for GBS prophylaxis. The colonization often recurs after oral treatment, and the timing of labor onset is unpredictable.

 

Administer a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone at the onset of labor (Option C): While ceftriaxone is active against GBS, a single intramuscular dose is not the recommended regimen. Continuous intravenous therapy during labor is necessary to maintain adequate antibiotic levels.

 

No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth (Option D): No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth: This approach is not recommended as it fails to prevent vertical transmission of GBS during labor and delivery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation undergoes routine screening for Group B Streptococcus (GBS). The vaginal-rectal swab culture shows beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm GBS?

choices.text: Conduct a latex agglutination test for group B antigen

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Perform a CAMP test

 

Explanation:

The CAMP (Christie, Atkins, Munch-Petersen) test is a simple and specific test for presumptive identification of Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS). It detects the CAMP factor, a protein produced by GBS that enhances the hemolytic activity of Staphylococcus aureus beta-lysin.


 

A positive CAMP reaction is indicated by an arrowhead-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis where the GBS streak approaches the S. aureus streak.

 

GBS Diagnosis:

1. Culture on blood agar (beta-hemolytic colonies)

2. CAMP test (presumptive identification)

3. Latex agglutination or nucleic acid amplification tests for confirmation

4. Hippurate hydrolysis test (positive for GBS)

5. Resistance to bacitracin and optochin

 

GBS Treatment:

1. For neonatal sepsis: Ampicillin plus gentamicin empirically; adjust based on susceptibility

2. For maternal colonization: Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with penicillin G or ampicillin

3. For penicillin-allergic patients: Cefazolin (if low risk for anaphylaxis) or clindamycin/vancomycin (if high risk for anaphylaxis and isolate susceptible)

 

Conduct a latex agglutination test for group B antigen (Option B): Latex agglutination test for GBS is typically used for rapid detection from clinical specimens or for confirming isolates. The CAMP test is more cost-effective for initial presumptive identification.

 

Observe for orange pigment production (Option C): While some strains of GBS can produce an orange pigment, this characteristic is not consistent across all strains and is not a reliable method for identification.

 

Perform a bacitracin sensitivity test (Option D): The Bacitracin sensitivity test is primarily used for differentiating Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes), which is typically bacitracin-sensitive. It is not useful for identifying GBS.

questions.text: A full-term newborn develops respiratory distress, lethargy, and poor feeding within 24 hours of birth. The mother had no prenatal care. Blood culture grows gram-positive cocci in chains. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Early-onset Group B Streptococcal disease

 

Explanation:

  • Early-onset Group B Streptococcal (GBS)/ Streptococcus agalactiae disease typically presents within the first 24-48 hours of life.
  • The clinical features of respiratory distress, lethargy, and poor feeding are classic signs of neonatal sepsis.
  • The gram-positive cocci in chains from the blood culture are consistent with GBS. The unknown GBS status of the mother increases the risk for this condition.
  • Prevention strategies focus on screening pregnant women at 35-37 weeks gestation and providing intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis to GBS-positive mothers.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has a purulent discharge from a surgical wound after an abdominal surgery performed two weeks ago. An analysis of the discharge, reveals Gram-positive cocci. Further testing shows that the organism is catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis

Explanation:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is present on normal human skin and is the most common cause of CoNS infections in humans. When the host's defenses are breached (in this scenario it is the surgery), stitch abscess frequently results from it.

  • S. epidermidis, S.haemolyticus, and S.lugdunensis cause device-associated and healthcare-associated infections.
  • The most frequent cause of CoNS infections in people is S. epidermidis.
  • It causes biofilm formation and prosthetic heart valve infection( <12 months post-replacement)
  • It is normal skin flora and causes illness when the host's defenses are compromised. It frequently results in stitch abscesses.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and rash that started on the neck and chest and then spread to the trunk and extremities. Examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Scarlet fever

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation is classic for scarlet fever. This disease is caused by the Streptococcus pyogenes strain that produces pyrogenic exotoxins. The characteristic features include:

  • Fever and sore throat (streptococcal pharyngitis)
  • Sandpaper-like rash with Pastia’s lines that blanches on pressure

  • Rash typically starts on neck and chest, then spreads
  • "Strawberry tongue" (red, swollen tongue with prominent papillae)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Throat culture grows beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, and the isolate is identified as Streptococcus pyogenes. Which of the following virulence factors of S. pyogenes is primarily responsible for its ability to resist phagocytosis and contribute to invasive infections?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) M protein

 

Explanation:

 

  • M protein is a major virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) that plays a crucial role in resisting phagocytosis.
  • It's an anti-phagocytic surface protein that interferes with complement activation and opsonization, allowing the bacteria to evade the host's immune defenses.
  • The M protein also plays a role in adherence to epithelial cells and is implicated in the post-streptococcal sequelae due to molecular mimicry with human tissues

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a persistent fever and septicemia. Blood cultures show alpha-hemolytic growth on blood agar. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Explanation:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus commonly causing pneumonia, septicemia, and meningitis, especially in diabetic patients and those with other underlying health issues.

questions.text: A 26-year-old sexually active female comes with complaints of burning micturition and haematuria. On investigation, the causative agent is a gram-positive coccus which is coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Staphylococcus saprophyticus

Explanation:

The causative agent is a gram-positive coccus and is coagulase-negative. In a sexually active, the most common cause of a UTI, with the above features, is Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are part of the human body's normal flora.

  • Significant species include:
    • Staphylococcus epidermidis
    • Staphylococcus saprophyticus
    • Staphylococcus haemolyticus
    • Staphylococcus lugdunensis

Staphylococcus saprophyticus:

  • Commonly found on human skin and periurethral area
  • Causes urinary tract infections- second most common cause, especially in sexually active young women
  • Generally susceptible to most antibiotics
  • Resistant to nalidixic acid
  • Identifiable by its novobiocin resistance

Infections Caused by CoNS:

Staphylococcus epidermidis:

  • The most prevalent cause of CoNS infections
  • Commonly found on human skin

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option A): is also coagulase-negative, but it is more commonly associated with infections related to indwelling medical devices or prosthetic materials.

 

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): is a coagulase-positive organism

 

Staphylococcus haemolyticus (Option D): causes severe infections in several body systems including meningitis, endocarditis, prosthetic joint infections, and bacteremia, and is prevalent in the hospital environment

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a skin infection and he was started on benzylpenicillin. A culture was done when the patient failed to respond to the given treatment and methicillin resistance was detected. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Vancomycin.

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario depicts a case of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and the suitable drug for the same is Vancomycin.

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

  • Definition: MRSA is a type of Staphylococcus aureus resistant to methicillin and other β-lactam antibiotics.
  • Common Habitats: Found on human skin and mucous membranes; typically harmless unless entering through damaged skin.

Resistance Mechanism

  • Cause: Resistance arises from the Staphylococcal chromosomal cassette for methicillin resistance (SCCmec).
  • Key Proteins:
    • MecA: An alternative penicillin-binding protein encoded by SCCmec, not recognized by β-lactam antibiotics.
    • MecI and MecR1: Regulate MecA synthesis upon exposure to methicillin or other β-lactams.

Diagnostic Methods:

Diagnostic Method

Description

Culture-based techniques

Use of chromogenic agar media where MRSA colonies appear pink, and other bacteria appear blue.

Blood Sample Testing
  • 10–20 ml of venous blood is drawn and injected into two culture bottles, incubated aerobically and anaerobically at 35°C.
  • Automated systems detect growth via turbidity, fluorescence, O2 consumption, or CO2 production.
  • Most bacteria are recovered within 2 days. Gram staining and specialized media are used for further identification.

CSF Sample Testing
  • For suspected meningitis, a lumbar puncture is performed to obtain 3–5 ml of CSF.
  • Turbidity and high leukocyte counts indicate infection.
  • CSF is Gram-stained and inoculated onto selective culture media.

 

Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing- Confirmation of infection is followed by testing to determine the best treatment strategy.

 

Treatment Challenge

  • Treatment Options:
    • Vancomycin: Effective but challenged by vancomycin-resistant strains (VRSA) (Option B).
    • Linezolid: Primary treatment for VRSA especially Lung infections for other infections Daptomycin is used.
    • Concerns: Emergence of vancomycin-intermediate Staphylococcus aureus (VISA) with reduced vancomycin susceptibility and thickened cell walls
    • Tetracyclines
    • Sulpha-drugs.

 

Feature

Other Options (Ceftazidime, Ceftriaxone, and Amoxicillin): are β-lactam antibiotics and therefore are ineffective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with a chronic foot ulcer showing signs of infection. Which laboratory test is most appropriate for identifying the causative organism, suspected to be Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Culture on blood agar

 

Explanation:

  • The use of blood agar culture is considered the primary method for isolating and identifying bacterial pathogens from clinical samples.
  • It is the gold standard method for isolating and identifying bacterial pathogens from clinical specimens.
  • Staphylococcus aureus typically forms creamy white colonies on blood agar plates, which helps in its identification

 

Step:

Description:

Specimen Collection
  • Pus samples from suppurative lesions, sputum for respiratory infections, nasal swabs for carriers

Direct Microscopy
  • Gram staining reveals Gram-positive cocci in clusters, indicating staphylococci presence (Option A)
  • Grape bunch- appearance

 

Culture
  • Culturing on blood agar to isolate and identify S. aureus colonies (Option C)
  • Blood agar: beta hemolysis
  • Nutrient agar: golden colonies

Selective Media
  • Salt-milk agar, Ludlam's medium, or Roberts' cooked meat medium to isolate S. aureus from mixed samples
  • Mannitol salt agar- yellow color from S. aureus fermenting mannitol

Biochemical Reactions
  • Coagulase test: Detects S. aureus by its ability to clot plasma (positive result indicates S. aureus)
  • Catalase test: Positive

Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing
  • Determines antibiotic sensitivity to guide treatment decisions (Option D)

Molecular Methods
  • PCR to detect specific genes like mecA, associated with antibiotic resistance (Option B)



 

Typing Method

Description

Examples

Phenotypic Typing
  • Relies on observable characteristics like antibiotic susceptibility or bacteriophage response.
  • Method: Classifies strains based on susceptibility to specific bacteriophages.
  • Limitations: Not all cultures are typeable; susceptibility patterns can change.

Bacteriophage typing

Genotypic Typing
  • Analyzes genetic characteristics of bacteria for strain differentiation.
  • Benefits: Offers higher discriminatory power, valuable in outbreak investigations.

DNA fingerprinting (e.g., RFLP, ribotyping)

PCR-based methods, PFGE, MLST

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with high fever, diffuse macular rash, hypotension, purulent vaginal discharge, and desquamation of the skin on her palms and soles. She has used tampons during her recent menstrual cycle and forgot to remove them on time. Laboratory tests reveal a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. Which toxin is primarily responsible for the condition observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Toxic shock syndrome toxin

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the woman is suffering from Toxic shock syndrome due to tampon use, which is often associated with Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Bacteria produce Toxic shock syndrome toxin, a superantigen that can trigger a massive immune response causing high fever, rash, hypotension, and desquamation.


 

Disease caused by staphylococcus

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis

  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option D)


Beta-hemolysin is not responsible for Toxic shock syndrome (Option C)

questions.text: Bronchopneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus infection is suspected in a 40-year-old patient. Which diagnostic test utilizes protein A to detect the presence of this bacteria?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Co agglutination test

 

Explanation:

 

Protein A binds to the Fc region of IgG, allowing Staphylococcus aureus to be coated with antibodies. The coated bacteria are then used to detect the presence of Staphylococcus aureus antigens in the test sample through visible clumping.


Coagulase test (Option A): Coagulase produced by Staphylococcus aureus causes the clotting of blood plasma by converting fibrinogen to fibrin. There are two types of coagulase tests: the slide coagulase test and the tube coagulase test.

 

Oxidase test (Option C): is used to determine the presence of cytochrome oxidase in bacteria

 

Catalase test (Option D): is used to identify the presence of the enzyme catalase in bacteria, which breaks down hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) into water and oxygen.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, and widespread peeling of the skin, especially around the face and trunk. The causative organism is identified as a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive coccus. Which virulence factor of this organism is responsible for the clinical manifestation observed in this child?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Exfoliative toxin

 

Explanation:

In this scenario, the child is suffering from Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), which is caused due to the Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin of Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is a skin condition caused by Staphylococcus aureus bacteria that produce exfoliative toxins. These toxins cause the skin to blister and peel, resembling burns.

  • Affects: Primarily infants and young children, but can also occur in immunocompromised adults.
  • Symptoms: Fever, red, tender skin that blisters and peels, especially on the face and neck. Nikolsky's sign (skin sloughing with pressure) is often positive.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical, supported by bacterial cultures or detection of exfoliative toxins.
  • Treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., nafcillin, clindamycin) and supportive care (fluids, wound care).
  • Prognosis: Good with prompt treatment, though severe cases can be life-threatening in infants or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Virulence factors

 

Key features

Peptidoglycan

Teichoic acid

Adherence to the host cell surface, and shields them from complement-mediated opsonization

  • Most cases are caused by type A.
  • It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system causing symptoms. Vomiting is stimulated in the brain stem.

  • Tampon-related TSS

  • Severe form of SSSS: Ritter's disease in the newborn and toxic epidermal necrolysis in older patients.
  • Milder forms: pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a purulent discharge from the wound. The laboratory identifies the causative bacteria to be gram-positive cocci, non-motile, non-spore-forming, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive. Which notable characteristic of this organism is seen when cultured on nutrient agar helps in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Golden pigment production

 

Explanation:

On nutrient agar, after 24 hours of incubation, Staphylococcus aureus produces golden-yellow pigment.

 

Key features of staphylococcus aureus:

 

Morphology

  • Gram-positive bacteria
  • Spherical cocci, arranged in grape-like clusters
  • Non-motile
  • Non-spore forming

 

Cultural characteristics

  • Nutrient agar: Large colonies (2-4 mm in diameter), convex, smooth, shiny, opaque, and easily emulsifiable. They produce golden-yellow pigment (Option D), which does not diffuse into the medium.

  • Blood agar: Marked hemolysis
  • MacConkey agar: Pink colonies due to lactose fermentation (Option A)

 

Biochemical characteristics:

  • Coagulase test positive
  • Catalase test positive
  • Oxidase negative


 

Incorrect options:

 

Blue-green pigment (Option B): (Pyocyanin) is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

 

Matt-finely granular colony (Option C): is characteristic of virulent strains of streptococcus pyogenes when grown in blood agar.
